speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: SCENE III. The plains near Rouen.

speaker: TALBOT
text_entry: Enter CHARLES, the BASTARD OF ORLEANS, ALENCON, JOAN LA PUCELLE, and forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Dismay not, princes, at this accident,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Nor grieve that Rouen is so recovered:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Care is no cure, but rather corrosive,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: For things that are not to be remedied.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And like a peacock sweep along his tail;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: We'll pull his plumes and take away his train,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: If Dauphin and the rest will be but ruled.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: We have been guided by thee hitherto,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And of thy cunning had no diffidence:

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: Search out thy wit for secret policies,

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And we will make thee famous through the world.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: We'll set thy statue in some holy place,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And have thee reverenced like a blessed saint:

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By fair persuasions mix'd with sugar'd words

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: We will entice the Duke of Burgundy

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To leave the Talbot and to follow us.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: France were no place for Henry's warriors;

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Nor should that nation boast it so with us,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: But be extirped from our provinces.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: For ever should they be expulsed from France

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And not have title of an earldom here.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Your honours shall perceive how I will work

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: To bring this matter to the wished end.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Drum sounds afar off

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Hark! by the sound of drum you may perceive

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Here sound an English march. Enter, and pass over at a distance, TALBOT and his forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: There goes the Talbot, with his colours spread,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And all the troops of English after him.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: French march. Enter BURGUNDY and forces

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Now in the rearward comes the duke and his:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Fortune in favour makes him lag behind.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Summon a parley; we will talk with him.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Trumpets sound a parley

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: The princely Charles of France, thy countryman.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: What say'st thou, Charles? for I am marching hence.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Speak, Pucelle, and enchant him with thy words.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France!

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Stay, let thy humble handmaid speak to thee.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Speak on; but be not over-tedious.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Look on thy country, look on fertile France,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And see the cities and the towns defaced

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: By wasting ruin of the cruel foe.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: As looks the mother on her lowly babe

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When death doth close his tender dying eyes,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: See, see the pining malady of France;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Behold the wounds, the most unnatural wounds,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Which thou thyself hast given her woful breast.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: O, turn thy edged sword another way;

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: One drop of blood drawn from thy country's bosom

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Should grieve thee more than streams of foreign gore:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Return thee therefore with a flood of tears,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And wash away thy country's stained spots.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Either she hath bewitch'd me with her words,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Or nature makes me suddenly relent.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Besides, all French and France exclaims on thee,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Doubting thy birth and lawful progeny.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Who joint'st thou with but with a lordly nation

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: That will not trust thee but for profit's sake?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: When Talbot hath set footing once in France

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And fashion'd thee that instrument of ill,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Who then but English Henry will be lord

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And thou be thrust out like a fugitive?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Call we to mind, and mark but this for proof,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Was not the Duke of Orleans thy foe?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And was he not in England prisoner?

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: But when they heard he was thine enemy,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: They set him free without his ransom paid,

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: In spite of Burgundy and all his friends.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: See, then, thou fight'st against thy countrymen

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: And joint'st with them will be thy slaughtermen.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Come, come, return; return, thou wandering lord:

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: Charles and the rest will take thee in their arms.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: I am vanquished; these haughty words of hers

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Have batter'd me like roaring cannon-shot,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And made me almost yield upon my knees.

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: Forgive me, country, and sweet countrymen,

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: And, lords, accept this hearty kind embrace:

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: My forces and my power of men are yours:

speaker: BURGUNDY
text_entry: So farewell, Talbot; I'll no longer trust thee.

speaker: JOAN LA PUCELLE
text_entry: [Aside]  Done like a Frenchman: turn, and turn again!

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Welcome, brave duke! thy friendship makes us fresh.

speaker: BASTARD OF ORLEANS
text_entry: And doth beget new courage in our breasts.

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: Pucelle hath bravely play'd her part in this,

speaker: ALENCON
text_entry: And doth deserve a coronet of gold.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Now let us on, my lords, and join our powers,

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: And seek how we may prejudice the foe.

speaker: CHARLES
text_entry: Exeunt
